text: so thank you so much everyone for having
me and it's amazing to be able to file
no such a great keynote speaker I will
add a disclaimer i use both the words
diversity and inclusion in my talk and
now i feel like i should substitute it
with some sort of nonsense word that
maybe we'll catch on as a result of this
conference but we'll see so i'm going to
be talking today about work family and
stigma breaking the silence for families
who don't fit and i'll give you a little
bit of background on how i began
studying this topic so i was studying
work and family proper as a graduate
student at Penn State my master's thesis
examined female breadwinners and the
distribution of household labor
specifically in heterosexual couples and
I was enrolled in a duel ph.d program
which I later graduated from in
industrial organizational psychology and
Women's Studies so it's always
interesting talking about LGBT issues to
management offices and whip departments
and Women's Studies departments in
women's studies departments they're like
yeah yeah LGBT but what's this stuff
about capitalism and in management
departments it's sort of the opposite
right so so it's interesting talking to
an interdisciplinary audience but I
think that these interdisciplinary
conversations like the ones that we're
having right now are really massively
useful in discovering things that are
right under our noses concepts that are
not on our radar in one field but which
are focal points in another field and so
was the case as I was studying io
psychology and Women's Studies I was
taking a Women's Studies course at the
same time as I was writing this thesis
on work and family and it was called Sex
in the City and it was a feminist
geography course taught by Melissa right
who's amazing and it was a class about
the ways in which individuals could
express or not express queer sexuality
depending upon their location so we
looked at urban sexualities and rural
sexualities and suburban sexualities and
so a main takeaway from this class was
that individuals who are non normatively
identified often have secret languages
and their enclaves and meeting places
and parties and gatherings and there are
these markers of queerness right and in
this case it was queer sexuality that
you would recognize if you knew what to
look for but which you wouldn't notice
if you weren't in the know right and as
a result of this class and in
conjunction with my training as an IO
psychologist I began to think about the
ways in which queer identities might
function in work and family spheres and
so what I found out was that there isn't
obviously a small but existent
literature on LGV populations in the
workplace and a much more larger
literature on identity at work more
broadly and so that's where I started
however while most identity research and
lgb research deals with managing
personal stigmatized identities I found
myself thinking about lgb denti teased a
little bit differently and this is
because by merit of the fact that these
identities are relational it has
something to do with who are you
attracted to or who do people imagine
you're attracted to they were somewhat
manifested by the presence of a same-sex
partner at least by the imagined
presence of one so lgb identities
precluded a sort of relationship with
others or an anticipated relationship
with others or a lack of a relationship
with others but one that was imagined by
a perceiver and yet i could find very
little about lgb families in the
literature so I started to ask these
questions and I had this vision of
myself in my 500 square foot apartment
in state college with these hundreds of
work-family articles and I'm going
through going they're not in here
they're not in here right where are
these lgb families hiding and this
became a really central question to both
my dissertation and it remains a central
question within my current work as a
faculty member at Villanova so as a
little bit of background on the academic
literature on what is work family
conflict it's a form of intellect in
which work and family domains are
incompatible in some respect and
generally this has been conceptualized
with regard to these three main
dimensions time strain and behavior so I
just don't have enough time to get my
family stuff done I feel stressed in one
domain Lee bleeds into another domain or
the behaviors that work for me in one
domain don't really work in another
domain and there's not that these
dimensions are bad but I believe that
they're incomplete and I started to
believe even more that they were
incomplete the more I started to look
into these sort of queer family
structures so what were some limitations
of work family conflict so there was no
real radical examination of family
structure or family type and so um while
we had things about single-family
single-parent families or we had things
about adopting children here and there
we didn't really have this radical
examination look what is family what do
we mean when we say that what are the
assumptions going on and we didn't
really ask about sexuality when
administering work family conflict
surveys or when studying work family
conflict in the workplace so we have
this general set of demographics you
know race gender age etc and we weren't
asking about sexuality in those
questions so we really were unsure
about how work family conflict was even
experienced and basically what that
meant was that all of these you know
queer families non-normative families
we're sort of going under the radar so
I'm a work family researcher I'm going
to do a study on working family and I
give out a bunch of surveys about work
and family and if I'm a person that's in
a non-normative structure I may have
some things I want to report on that
survey but there's no place for me to do
it so I'm responding to the items that
you're giving me and saying yeah that
yeah that yeah that but there's this
other thing and there's no way for me to
tell you as a researcher that that other
thing is missing from this survey right
so I decided to take an intersectional
approach to remedy this issue looking at
more layered family identities and
trying to understand how I might convey
the experiences of those layered family
identities from a work and family
perspective so why did I start with lgb
populations well it seemed like a way to
sort of focus my study to begin with
you'll see I broaden it out a little bit
more but you can see and I'm sure you're
aware of the fact that there are lots of
lgb discrimination cases that are in the
public eye even right now you may have
seen in recent news states are actually
passing laws that prohibit the passage
of protections that would shield LGBT
individuals from discrimination and
protections which would provide equal
access to employment and facilities so
these issues continue to be publicly
debated hotly publicly debated and there
are still many people who fall on the
pro discrimination side of this debate
and I use that word very deliberately
pro discrimination I believe that that's
what it is so there are plenty of
reasons for us to believe that lgb
populations might face different sorts
of experiences in the workplace so with
all of this documented discrimination
towards lgb individuals the experience
of work family conflict I believed when
I embarked on this project and even more
strongly now may be different for
members of an LG be relationship or
family so my main research questions
when I embarked on my dissertation was
how do lgb individuals experience work
family conflict so if I asked you the
question what's work family conflict
mean to you without a prompt without
having these dimensions in place without
a measure in front of you that tells you
what it is how do you respond and are
these experiences different from our
notions of traditional work family
conflict so what are we missing and are
these experience is only relevant to lgb
families are they also relevant to
families with stigmatized identities
more broadly and this is something that
I embarked upon later on that I'll talk
about so in order to understand these
questions I actually collected some
qualitative data to get a deeper
understanding of the work family
experiences of those in lgb families and
I ended up with 41 usable interviews
from lgb individuals working full or
part-time and identifying as members of
same-sex couples and who also considered
themselves members of families and I
asked them these very open-ended
questions about work and family and then
I ask them some more specific questions
about the dimensions that they reported
back to me so here's the big old model
and I know it's a little fuzzy but I'm
giving you this to show that there's a
lot here and I'm going to hone in on
sort of this key central experience of
work-family conflict stemming from
perceived membership in a stigmatized
family and of course i'm adding this
word perceived because we don't have
another person reporting yes I feel that
that family structure is wrong right but
the person feels this stigma themselves
so it's a perception so the first kind
of experience that sort of shook out
that was different from our traditional
work family conflict literature was this
suspicion and trust based conflict and
so this sort of had a couple of
different dimensions one this is from a
couple of co-workers who work together
but we're in a romantic relationship in
our last job we work together but we
weren't out we didn't trust the
co-workers very much they thought we
were cousins or something because we
were always hanging out and then another
quote from someone who actually was very
much out but felt a lot of suspicion in
terms of when and where to share family
related information anytime people talk
about relationships I'm thinking about
what to say I don't want to lie i try to
be honest without giving too much
information and you'll see this theme a
lot that it's not the same thing as
disclosure so a lot of the LGBT
literature is about you tell people that
you're gay and that's an action and yes
it's a journey and you keep telling
people in the more people you tell the
more out you are and that's certainly
true but it doesn't capture these
nuances of now that you know how
frequently do I bring it up in what ways
and this is a real my participants at
least the participants in this study
felt like that was a real work family
issue and defined it as a work family
issue so this is another quote from
someone who was working in an academic
institution with a spousal higher and
started to get the suspicion that the
office was working a little less hard
to get his partner a spousal higher than
they had worked with other people and he
states it became hard to avoid the
suspicion that it was because we were
gay but I can't prove that it has to do
with identities so moving forward he
talked about how he sort of acted in the
institution differently than he would
have had he not had these experiences
this other form of conflict that we
picked up on was his identity
fragmentation based and so this had to
do with really separating parts of
yourself between home and work and
shutting off your home identity in the
workplace and shutting off your work
identity at home because people were
actually embarrassed that they weren't
talking about their family enough at at
work so they actually talk less about
work at home too so a couple of quotes
here I guess I would think about work
family conflict it's that I feel fully
inhibited to be myself at work so it's
like these two different contrasting
personalities that create conflict for
me dealing with people at work and then
it leads to distraction thinking about
that at home another person said every
organization is different but when to
talk about my family with customers or
clients that's something that a straight
person wouldn't have to think about and
so this person was specifically saying
every time I enter into a client meeting
I'm leaving a part of myself out because
most client meetings you walk into
they're not like hey Joe are you gay
right but they might say hey Joe tell me
about your weekend how are your kids
rights you have kids are you married and
this starts a family related
conversation that also has something to
do with this stigma and then the last
one this person actually felt
fragmentation because they were bringing
past closeted versions of themselves
into the workplace which I thought was
really interesting so I can't let any of
this out at work I channel my high
school self at work this is the first
and foremost thing that I think of when
I think of work family conflict so for
authenticity this was sort of the last
step and I want to highlight that this
was really regardless of who was out how
they were out it didn't matter people
felt this sense of when and how was very
important so this person felt
inauthentic actually toward their
partner I felt like I was doing my
partner a disservice because i was out
everywhere else except work and i felt
too faced but i had to do it this next
quote i can't think of an example of
work-family conflict except around
issues of identity I do feel that my
work identity is not exactly conflicting
but my institutions not always conducive
to my own home happiness and then the
last person this is an interesting
situation so this person was extremely
authentic in at work he prided himself
on I share information about my partner
I talk about my family this is an
academic this is a professor and talked
with students in fact about these issues
and so he had shared a pretty personal
story about he and his partner going on
vacation together not inappropriate but
personal and says after that I had a
really uncomfortable situation where a
student called me a gay slur I'm in
front of the class and so after class I
followed him into the hallway and asked
did you just call me a gay slur and he
goes on to say I was terrified that I
that I would be fired because I had
confronted the student and afterwards
one of the people in student services
said that I was becoming unglued because
I approached him about it so moving
forward this person felt less free to be
authentic in class because he felt I can
be authentic about my family and then
learned oh wait no i can write I don't
have the support of my institution so
there were a couple behavioral taxes
that I'll just talk about quickly that's
stemmed from these we found that people
verbally suppressed or fabricated family
information at work physically separated
working families so this was a big theme
that came out that people really felt
that I don't have the luxury of picking
whether I mesh or separate my family
life which is one of these key
strategies you integrate you segment
right that we talked about in work in
life research they felt in many
instances I was forced to separate I
didn't have that integration option so
this person says I told my partner not
to come to work to visit me because he
would have to conform more than I would
if he came to visit me at work and I
don't feel like there's a place for him
in my work of environment such that he
could comfortably visit me another
person in this differential disclosure
which relates back to bail Reagan's his
work on invisible stigma and disclosure
um differential disclosure of family
information so this person worked in a
retirement community was out to
everybody actually brought her partner
with her to events but when residents
would ask who's that person she would be
like it's my friend or whatever you know
and they couldn't show any affection to
each other in that space because she
felt uncomfortable with different
constituencies we also saw some
biological taxes that stemmed from this
stigmatized family identity first was
minority stress so people felt singled
out they felt when people talked about
families even if people knew they were
gay that when people had family
conversations they felt singled out
problematized right so this person says
I'm always on edge with the fear that
people would ask about my family people
also felt depersonalized sort of this
floating like I'm not really myself at
work because I had this strong family
identity that I'm not bringing in I'm
not really myself at home because I'm
embarrassed to talk about the fact that
I don't talk about my family at work so
I'm sort of drifting away from people in
both domains so this person said her
partner wants to talk about on the phone
at work she doesn't feel comfortable and
that makes her feel distant from her
partner and denial of personal dignity
so I like this quote this person said a
co-worker said my cousin finally got
married and I wanted to say finally what
does that mean did that person have no
value without marriage right and so
these assumptive comments made people
feel like their dignity was being
stripped in a particular kind of way in
the workplace we also had a situation I
interviewed a bartender and her partner
came into the workplace to visit her and
they showed some sort of infection and a
customer said something the slower made
a comment and it sort of escalated so
she went to go get her manager to say
you know this customers giving my
partner a hard time and she was actually
great friends with the manager and
really thought he was going to come out
there and tell the customer what for and
he basically told her you gotta tell
your partner to leave and she reported
to me that this made some really serious
problems for her at home because her
partner kept saying her you got to go
back in there and you have to tell him
and she's like but we need the money I
don't know if I want to confront him and
so they were fighting and there was
anxiety and she was exhausted and all of
this sort of perfect storm of
work-family stigma came together so one
thing I will touch on him that some
people ask about is whether or not this
is unique to those with stigmatized
families or do more traditional families
experience this and actually we did run
a comparison sample so take a look at
whether or not traditional heterosexual
families experience this and what we
found when we really took like
traditional nuclear families was that no
they did not experience this we actually
did a perfectly paired samples same
institutions same job role paired people
together found that LGB people were
saying yeah this is happening straight
people were not reporting these sorts of
things but one of the things that was
unique was that we act
I ended up with a lot of people in our
sample who we embarked upon saying hey
your traditional nuclear family why
don't you talk to us and partway through
the interview we realized that they were
reporting stigma to relational stigma
and so we had people in our sample that
made us ask this broader question does
this apply to a broader sample of
stigmatized families so right now we're
in this exploratory study phase we've
interviewed 15 people so far people in
interracial relationships people who are
in relationships with religious
minorities gender minorities single
women of color we have lots of people in
the sample right now but we're working
on broadening that sample even more and
basically what we found was that the
model replicated but it added some
nuances and the first of those nuances
was that depending upon whether or not
people perceived that stigma as being
controllable predicted whether or not
people experience that same kind of
conflict so this quote is from a man
whose wife was diagnosed with MS and he
actually felt that his co-workers were
very supportive he said I think my work
family conflict went down they were
making dinner for us they were doing all
these things outpouring of support when
I pushed back on him and said well why
do you think that is he said well you
know I would have thought that if you
had an abuse issue either alcohol or
drugs that might have been seen as
something which you could have some
control over and therefore if you didn't
want that to be a problem do something
about it whereas an illness unless you
went off to the Amazon and didn't get
your shots expose yourself to a bunch of
badness sort of like blows in the wind
right so his thought was because people
saw it as being uncontrollable he didn't
experience that similarly we also found
that if people thought that the stigma
was dangerous and I won't read this
whole quote but you can look at it this
woman had two children with autism and
she felt that public persona around
autism was that they're not dangerous
people they're not people committing
crimes they're not people to fear so she
didn't feel that same sort of stigma
however we have someone else in the
study who is in a family relationship
with someone who has schizophrenia and
similar levels of may be perceived
controllability but that person was
perceived as very dangerous and so what
does that person going to do and she
felt more conflict over that as opposed
to or compared to this woman with
autistic children we also found that
stigmatized individual identities played
a role so if you already held a
stigmatized identity that
intersectionality sort of exacerbated
those pieces so this person is a black
single woman comparing herself to
another black woman in her department
who has children and she
says that must be nice i don't need to
put when i pick up my kids in the
planner because i have to pick them up
every day right so people think that i
have this great role model and this
other black mom but she's got a husband
right and that makes things different
for me and gender also predicted
somewhat whether or not people
experienced these sorts of issues so
what are some takeaways here we found
that families that perceived stigma in
the workplace do experience unique forms
of work family conflict and unique
behavioral and psychological taxes that
sort of operate over and above the
normal traditional kinds of work and
family conflict and those sorts of
outcomes and when lgb participants also
reported experienced experiencing
traditional conflict these additional
layers created exacerbating work family
challenges that have previously gone
undetected and now we hope to detect and
if organizations want to create
comprehensive solutions and actually be
focused on diversity they need to be
really thinking about whose voices have
not been represented who has been
silenced so far when we're thinking
about policies that actually affect
large groups of people so a couple
questions what does your organization
mean when they say the word family are
stigmatized family suffering and hidden
in plain sight does your organization
have true equality and I really hated
typing the word Trump but it was the
most concise way that I could say it
cuts across work and family domain so
what is your culture what is the formal
and informal language that people are
using around family that may reinforce
experiences and not just what the policy
states on the books and I believe that
we have a social responsibility to
further examine the intersections
between work family conflict stigma and
identity management in order to create a
better world increased life satisfaction
and job satisfaction as a result of
having a truly thoughtful critical look
at who is in and who is out of
conversations about work and family so
thank you
